metadata.description: Traditional Malay dishes popular in Singapore, featuring aromatic spices, coconut milk, and rich flavors

recipes.name: Nasi Lemak
recipes.description: Fragrant coconut rice served with various accompaniments
steps: Wash rice and drain
Cook rice with coconut milk, pandan leaves, and salt
For sambal: Blend chilies, shallots, garlic, and belacan
Fry sambal in oil until fragrant, add tamarind juice and sugar
Serve rice with sambal and accompaniments
tips: Use fresh coconut milk for best flavor
The sambal should be spicy and slightly sweet
Serve with additional protein like fried chicken or fish
recipes.origin: Nasi Lemak is considered Malaysia's national dish but is also very popular in Singapore, often eaten for breakfast or as a complete meal.

recipes.name: Mee Soto
recipes.description: Spicy Malay-style chicken noodle soup with yellow noodles, shredded chicken, and aromatic spices.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add chicken stock, bring to boil. Add chicken breasts, simmer until cooked, then shred.
Blanch noodles, place in bowls. Top with shredded chicken, potatoes, bean sprouts, egg, fried shallots, and spring onions.
Ladle hot soup over and serve.
tips: Use kampung chicken for a richer broth.
Serve with sambal kicap (spicy soy sauce).
recipes.origin: Mee Soto is a Malay-Indonesian noodle soup popular in Singapore, especially at Malay hawker stalls.

recipes.name: Nasi Lemak
recipes.description: Fragrant coconut rice served with fried ikan bilis, peanuts, egg, cucumber, sambal, and chicken wing.

rice.jasmine rice: 2 cups, cooked with coconut milk and pandan leaf

steps: Cook rice with coconut milk, pandan leaf, and salt.
Fry ikan bilis and peanuts until crispy.
Fry or boil eggs. Fry chicken wings until golden.
Serve rice with all toppings and sambal.
tips: Use pandan leaf for authentic aroma.
Serve with spicy sambal for best flavor.
recipes.origin: Nasi Lemak is a Malay classic, beloved at breakfast and lunch across Singapore.

recipes.name: Nasi Goreng
recipes.description: Indonesian-style fried rice with egg, prawns, chicken, and vegetables, seasoned with kecap manis and sambal.
steps: Heat oil, fry garlic until fragrant.
Add chicken and prawns, stir-fry until cooked.
Add vegetables, then rice. Stir-fry to combine.
Add sauces, toss well. Serve topped with fried egg and spring onions.
tips: Use day-old rice for best texture.
Add chili padi for extra heat.
recipes.origin: Nasi Goreng is a staple at Malay and Indonesian hawker stalls in Singapore.

recipes.name: Satay
recipes.description: Grilled skewers of marinated meat served with spicy peanut sauce, ketupat, onions, and cucumber.
steps: Mix marinade ingredients, coat meat, and marinate for at least 2 hours.
Thread meat onto skewers and grill over charcoal until cooked and slightly charred.
For sauce: fry chili paste, add peanuts, tamarind, sugar, and water. Simmer until thickened.
Serve satay with peanut sauce, ketupat, cucumber, and onion.
tips: Use chicken thigh for juicier satay.
Grill over charcoal for authentic flavor.
recipes.origin: Satay is a Malay-style grilled meat skewer, a staple at night markets and hawker centres.

recipes.name: Assam Pedas
recipes.description: Spicy and sour fish stew with tamarind, chili, and assorted vegetables, a classic Malay dish.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add tamarind juice, water, sugar, and salt. Bring to a boil.
Add fish and vegetables, simmer until cooked through.
Serve hot with steamed rice.
tips: Use fresh fish for best results.
Adjust tamarind and chili to taste.
recipes.origin: Assam Pedas is a tangy, spicy Malay stew, popular at nasi padang stalls.

recipes.name: Ayam Penyet
recipes.description: Indonesian-style smashed fried chicken served with sambal, fried tofu, tempeh, and rice.
steps: Marinate chicken for at least 1 hour.
Deep-fry chicken until golden and crispy. Smash gently with a pestle.
Serve with fried tofu, tempeh, sambal, and rice.
tips: Use kampung chicken for best texture.
Serve with extra sambal for heat.
recipes.origin: Ayam Penyet is an Indonesian fried chicken dish, popular at Malay and Indonesian stalls.

recipes.name: Dendeng Paru
recipes.description: Spicy, sweet, and crispy beef lung slices, a festive Malay delicacy.
steps: Boil beef lung until tender, slice thinly.
Marinate with spices and garlic, then deep-fry until crispy.
Toss with chili sauce and palm sugar. Serve as a snack or with rice.
tips: Slice lung thinly for crispiness.
Adjust chili and sugar to taste.
recipes.origin: Dendeng Paru is a festive treat, often served during Hari Raya.

recipes.name: Lemak Siput
recipes.description: River snails cooked in spicy coconut gravy with turmeric, lemongrass, and chili.
steps: Fry garlic, shallots, and chili paste until fragrant.
Add coconut milk, turmeric, and lemongrass. Bring to a simmer.
Add snails, cook until tender. Season with salt and serve.
tips: Use fresh snails for best flavor.
Simmer gently to avoid tough snails.
recipes.origin: Lemak Siput is a traditional Malay dish, found at festive stalls and markets.

recipes.name: Gudeg Putih
recipes.description: Javanese-style young jackfruit stew in coconut milk, subtly sweet and aromatic.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add jackfruit, coconut milk, palm sugar, salt, and water. Simmer 2 hours until jackfruit is tender and flavors meld.
Serve with steamed rice.
tips: Use fresh young jackfruit for best texture.
Let stew rest overnight for deeper flavor.
recipes.origin: Gudeg Putih is a Javanese specialty, sometimes found at Malay and Indonesian stalls in Singapore.

recipes.name: Gulai Daun Ubi
recipes.description: Spicy coconut curry of cassava leaves, chilies, and anchovies, a Minangkabau favorite.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add cassava leaves, coconut milk, anchovies, salt, and water. Simmer 1 hour until leaves are tender.
Serve with steamed rice.
tips: Use young cassava leaves for tenderness.
Add more chilies for extra heat.
recipes.origin: Gulai Daun Ubi is a Minangkabau dish, found at nasi padang stalls in Singapore.

recipes.name: Sayur Lodeh
recipes.description: Vegetable curry in coconut milk with cabbage, long beans, tofu, and tempeh, a Malay classic.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add vegetables, tofu, and tempeh. Stir to coat with spices.
Add coconut milk, lemongrass, bay leaf, salt, and water. Simmer 30â€“45 minutes until vegetables are tender.
Serve with steamed rice or lontong.
tips: Use fresh coconut milk for best flavor.
Add chili padi for extra heat.
recipes.origin: Sayur Lodeh is a Malay vegetable curry, often served with lontong or nasi impit.

recipes.name: Soto
recipes.description: Spiced chicken soup with vermicelli, bean sprouts, and potato cakes, a Malay-Indonesian favorite.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add chicken, brown lightly, then add water and salt. Simmer 1.5â€“2 hours until chicken is tender.
Shred chicken, serve soup with vermicelli, bean sprouts, begedil, fried shallots, and spring onions.
tips: Serve with sambal kicap for extra heat.
Use kampung chicken for richer broth.
recipes.origin: Soto is a Malay-Indonesian chicken soup, popular at hawker centres and Ramadan bazaars.

recipes.name: Soto Ayam
recipes.description: Indonesian-style chicken soup with turmeric, vermicelli, and shredded chicken, topped with fried shallots and celery.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add chicken, brown lightly, then add water and salt. Simmer 1.5â€“2 hours until chicken is tender.
Shred chicken, serve soup with vermicelli, bean sprouts, egg, fried shallots, and celery leaves.
tips: Serve with sambal kicap for extra heat.
Use kampung chicken for richer broth.
recipes.origin: Soto Ayam is a Malay-Indonesian chicken soup, popular at hawker centres and Ramadan bazaars.

recipes.name: Minangkabau Beef Rendang
recipes.description: Dry, aromatic beef curry slow-cooked with coconut, spices, and chilies, a festive Minangkabau specialty.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add beef, brown lightly, then add coconut milk, kerisik, tamarind, salt, and water. Simmer 2â€“3 hours until beef is tender and sauce is thick and dry.
Serve with steamed rice or ketupat.
tips: Use shin or brisket for best texture.
Let rendang rest overnight for deeper flavor.
recipes.origin: Beef Rendang is a Minangkabau festive dish, beloved at Malay weddings and celebrations.

recipes.name: Putu Mayam
recipes.description: Steamed rice flour noodles served with grated coconut and gula melaka, a South Indian-Malay breakfast treat.
steps: Mix rice flour, water, and salt to form a dough. Press through a putu mayam mould onto banana leaves.
Steam for 5â€“7 minutes until cooked.
Serve with grated coconut and gula melaka.
tips: Use a traditional mould for authentic texture.
Serve immediately for best softness.
recipes.origin: Putu Mayam is a South Indian-Malay breakfast dish, popular at hawker centres and markets.

recipes.name: Daging Kicap
recipes.description: Malay-style beef braised in sweet soy sauce with onions, potatoes, and spices.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add beef, brown lightly, then add kicap manis, potatoes, onion, chili, water, and salt. Simmer 45â€“60 minutes until beef and potatoes are tender.
Serve with steamed rice.
tips: Use shin or brisket for best texture.
Add more chili for extra heat.
recipes.origin: Daging Kicap is a Malay comfort food, found at nasi padang and Malay stalls.

recipes.name: Roti Boyan
recipes.description: Fried pastry stuffed with mashed potato, onions, and egg, a Malay-Indian snack.
steps: Mix dough ingredients, knead until smooth. Rest 30 minutes.
Mix filling ingredients. Divide dough, roll out, fill with potato mixture, seal edges.
Fry in hot oil until golden and crisp on both sides. Drain and serve warm.
tips: Serve with sambal or curry for dipping.
Add chopped sardines for variety.
recipes.origin: Roti Boyan is a Malay-Indian snack, popular at Ramadan bazaars and Malay stalls.

recipes.name: Kueh Tutu
recipes.description: Steamed rice flour cakes filled with grated coconut or peanut, a nostalgic Singapore street snack.
steps: Mix rice flour, water, and salt to form a crumbly dough.
Fill small moulds with dough, add filling, cover with more dough. Press and unmould onto banana leaf.
Steam for 5â€“7 minutes until cooked. Serve warm.
tips: Use traditional moulds for authentic shape.
Serve immediately for best softness.
recipes.origin: Kueh Tutu is a nostalgic Singapore street snack, found at pasar malams and food fairs.

recipes.name: Pulut Hitam
recipes.description: Black glutinous rice porridge cooked with coconut milk and gula melaka, a comforting dessert.
steps: Boil soaked rice with water and pandan leaves until soft and porridge-like (about 1 hour).
Stir in gula melaka and salt. Serve warm with coconut milk drizzled on top.
tips: Soak rice overnight for faster cooking.
Add more coconut milk for creaminess.
recipes.origin: Pulut Hitam is a Peranakan and Malay dessert, found at dessert stalls and food courts.

recipes.name: Apom Berkuah
recipes.description: Fluffy Malay pancakes made with coconut milk and yeast, served with banana sauce.
steps: Mix batter ingredients, let rise 1 hour.
Cook small pancakes on a nonstick pan until bubbles form and set.
For sauce: simmer bananas, coconut milk, sugar, and salt until thickened. Serve pancakes with sauce.
tips: Use overripe bananas for best flavor.
Serve warm for best texture.
recipes.origin: Apom Berkuah is a Malay dessert, popular at Ramadan bazaars and festive occasions.

recipes.name: Bubur Cha Cha
recipes.description: Colorful dessert of sweet potatoes, yam, sago, and tapioca jellies in coconut milk, a Peranakan and Malay classic.
steps: Boil sweet potatoes, yam, and sago until tender. Drain.
Simmer coconut milk, water, sugar, salt, and pandan leaves. Add cooked ingredients and tapioca jellies. Serve warm or chilled.
tips: Use a mix of sweet potato colors for visual appeal.
Add more sago for extra texture.
recipes.origin: Bubur Cha Cha is a Peranakan and Malay dessert, found at dessert stalls and festive occasions.

recipes.name: Ondeh Ondeh
recipes.description: Glutinous rice balls filled with molten gula melaka, coated in grated coconut, a beloved kueh.
steps: Mix flour, pandan juice, and water to form a soft dough. Wrap dough around gula melaka, roll into balls.
Boil balls until they float. Roll in salted grated coconut. Serve at room temperature.
tips: Use fresh pandan for best aroma.
Serve on day made for softest texture.
recipes.origin: Ondeh Ondeh is a Peranakan and Malay kueh, found at markets and dessert stalls.

recipes.name: Kueh Lapis
recipes.description: Steamed layered cake of coconut milk, rice flour, and tapioca flour, colored in rainbow layers, a festive treat.
steps: Mix all batter ingredients except coloring. Divide into portions, tint each with a different color.
Pour a thin layer into a greased pan, steam 5 minutes. Repeat with each color, steaming between layers, until all batter is used.
Cool, slice, and serve.
tips: Use a sharp knife for clean layers.
Peel layers apart for fun eating.
recipes.origin: Kueh Lapis is a festive layered kueh, popular at celebrations and markets.

recipes.name: Kueh Dadar
recipes.description: Pandan crepes filled with sweet coconut and gula melaka, a Peranakan and Malay tea-time treat.
steps: Mix crepe ingredients to form a thin batter. Cook thin crepes on a nonstick pan.
Simmer filling ingredients until thick and sticky. Cool.
Place filling on crepe, roll up, and serve.
tips: Use fresh pandan for best aroma.
Do not overfill crepes.
recipes.origin: Kueh Dadar is a Peranakan and Malay kueh, popular at tea time.

recipes.name: Putu Piring
recipes.description: Steamed rice flour cakes filled with molten gula melaka, served with grated coconut, a street snack.
steps: Mix rice flour, water, and salt to form a crumbly dough.
Fill small moulds with dough, add gula melaka, cover with more dough. Steam 5â€“7 minutes until cooked.
Serve with salted grated coconut.
tips: Use traditional moulds for authentic shape.
Serve immediately for best softness.
recipes.origin: Putu Piring is a street snack, found at pasar malams and food fairs.

recipes.name: Durian Pengat
recipes.description: Rich, creamy durian dessert with coconut milk and gula melaka, a Peranakan and Malay favourite.
steps: Simmer coconut milk, gula melaka, water, and salt until sugar dissolves.
Add durian flesh, cook gently until thick and creamy. Serve warm or chilled.
tips: Use ripe durian for best flavor.
Add sago pearls for extra texture.
recipes.origin: Durian Pengat is a Peranakan and Malay dessert, found at dessert stalls and festive occasions.

recipes.name: Sago Gula Melaka
recipes.description: Chilled sago pearls served with coconut milk and gula melaka syrup, a Peranakan and Malay dessert.
steps: Boil sago in plenty of water until translucent, drain and rinse.
Simmer gula melaka, water, and salt until syrupy.
Serve sago chilled with coconut milk and gula melaka syrup.
tips: Rinse sago well to remove excess starch.
Chill sago before serving for best texture.
recipes.origin: Sago Gula Melaka is a Peranakan and Malay dessert, found at dessert stalls and festive occasions.

recipes.name: Bubur Terigu
recipes.description: Sweet Indonesian-Malay dessert porridge of wheat pearls, coconut milk, and gula melaka.
steps: Boil soaked wheat pearls in water until soft (about 1 hour).
Stir in gula melaka and salt. Serve warm with coconut milk drizzled on top.
tips: Soak wheat pearls overnight for faster cooking.
Add more coconut milk for creaminess.
recipes.origin: Bubur Terigu is a Malay and Indonesian dessert, found at dessert stalls and festive occasions.

recipes.name: Ubi Kayu (Steamed Cassava Cake)
recipes.description: Steamed grated cassava cake with coconut and gula melaka, a traditional Malay and Peranakan snack.
steps: Mix all ingredients, pour into a greased tray.
Steam for 1 hour until set. Cool, slice, and serve.
tips: Use fresh cassava for best texture.
Add grated coconut on top for extra flavor.
recipes.origin: Ubi Kayu is a Malay and Peranakan snack, found at markets and food fairs.

recipes.name: Bingka Ubi (Baked Cassava Cake)
recipes.description: Baked grated cassava cake with coconut and gula melaka, a traditional Malay and Peranakan snack.
steps: Mix all ingredients, pour into a greased tray.
Bake at 180Â°C for 1 hour until golden and set. Cool, slice, and serve.
tips: Use fresh cassava for best texture.
Add grated coconut on top for extra flavor.
recipes.origin: Bingka Ubi is a Malay and Peranakan snack, found at markets and food fairs.

recipes.name: Kuih Talam
recipes.description: Two-layered steamed kueh with pandan and coconut layers, a festive Malay and Peranakan treat.
steps: Mix bottom layer ingredients, pour into greased tray, steam 20 minutes.
Mix top layer ingredients, pour over bottom layer, steam 30â€“40 minutes until set. Cool, slice, and serve.
tips: Use fresh pandan for best aroma.
Let kueh cool completely before slicing.
recipes.origin: Kuih Talam is a festive kueh, popular at celebrations and markets.

recipes.name: Kuih Kosui
recipes.description: Steamed brown sugar rice cakes coated in grated coconut, a Peranakan and Malay snack.
steps: Melt gula melaka in water, cool slightly. Mix with flours and lye water to form a batter.
Pour into small moulds, steam 20â€“30 minutes until set.
Roll cakes in salted grated coconut. Serve at room temperature.
tips: Use lye water for springier texture.
Serve on day made for best softness.
recipes.origin: Kuih Kosui is a Peranakan and Malay snack, found at markets and food fairs.

recipes.name: Pisang Goreng
recipes.description: Deep-fried battered bananas, a popular street snack in Singapore and Malaysia.
steps: Mix batter ingredients until smooth.
Dip bananas in batter, deep-fry in hot oil until golden and crisp. Drain and serve warm.
tips: Use pisang raja or pisang kepok for best texture.
Serve immediately for maximum crispiness.
recipes.origin: Pisang Goreng is a popular street snack, found at hawker centres and markets.

ingredient_breakdown.ingredient: ripe bananas (pisang raja or pisang kepok)

recipes.name: Kuih Sago
recipes.description: Steamed sago cakes coated in grated coconut, a chewy Peranakan and Malay snack.
steps: Mix sago, sugar, water, and coloring. Pour into a tray, steam 30 minutes until set.
Cool, cut into cubes, and roll in salted grated coconut. Serve at room temperature.
tips: Use food coloring for festive look.
Serve on day made for best texture.
recipes.origin: Kuih Sago is a Peranakan and Malay snack, found at markets and food fairs.

recipes.name: Kuih Keria
recipes.description: Sweet potato doughnuts glazed with sugar, a Malay and Peranakan snack.
steps: Mix dough ingredients, knead until smooth. Shape into rings.
Deep-fry in hot oil until golden. Drain.
Boil sugar and water to make syrup, toss doughnuts in syrup until coated and glossy. Cool before serving.
tips: Use orange sweet potatoes for color.
Glaze while doughnuts are still warm.
recipes.origin: Kuih Keria is a Malay and Peranakan snack, found at markets and food fairs.

recipes.name: Kuih Bahulu
recipes.description: Light, fluffy sponge cakes baked in moulds, a festive Malay and Peranakan treat.
steps: Beat eggs and sugar until thick and pale.
Fold in flour and baking powder. Pour into greased moulds.
Bake at 180Â°C for 15â€“20 minutes until golden and puffed. Cool before serving.
tips: Use traditional brass moulds for best results.
Serve with tea for a festive treat.
recipes.origin: Kuih Bahulu is a festive cake, popular at Hari Raya and Chinese New Year.

recipes.name: Kuih Kapit (Love Letters)
recipes.description: Crispy, thin rolled wafers baked in moulds, a festive treat for Chinese New Year and Hari Raya.
steps: Beat eggs and sugar until thick. Stir in coconut milk, flour, and cornstarch to form a thin batter.
Pour batter into heated kuih kapit moulds, bake over charcoal or electric fire until golden.
Quickly roll or fold wafers while hot. Cool and store airtight.
tips: Use traditional moulds for best aroma.
Work quickly to shape wafers before they cool.
recipes.origin: Kuih Kapit is a festive snack, popular at Chinese New Year and Hari Raya.

recipes.name: Apom Balik
recipes.description: Thick, fluffy pancakes filled with crushed peanuts, sugar, and sweet corn, a popular street snack.
steps: Mix batter ingredients, let rise 1 hour.
Pour batter into heated pan, cook until bubbles form. Sprinkle with filling, fold pancake in half, cook until golden. Slice and serve.
tips: Use a nonstick pan for easy release.
Add butter for extra richness.
recipes.origin: Apom Balik is a street snack, found at pasar malams and food fairs.

recipes.name: Kuih Apam
recipes.description: Steamed, fluffy rice flour cakes, sometimes colored and topped with grated coconut, a festive Malay and Peranakan treat.
steps: Mix batter ingredients, let rise 1 hour.
Pour into small moulds, steam 15â€“20 minutes until puffed and set.
Top with salted grated coconut and serve.
tips: Use food coloring for festive look.
Serve on day made for best softness.
recipes.origin: Kuih Apam is a festive kueh, popular at celebrations and markets.

recipes.name: Kuih Apom
recipes.description: Small, fluffy pancakes made with rice flour, coconut milk, and yeast, a Peranakan and Malay snack.
steps: Mix batter ingredients, let rise 1 hour.
Pour small rounds onto a heated nonstick pan, cook until bubbles form and set. Serve warm.
tips: Use food coloring for festive look.
Serve with grated coconut or kaya.
recipes.origin: Kuih Apom is a Peranakan and Malay snack, found at markets and food fairs.

recipes.name: Perut Kambing
recipes.description: Spicy, tangy Malay soup of mutton tripe, spices, and coconut milk, a festive specialty.
steps: Fry blended chillies, shallots, garlic, lemongrass, galangal, and ginger in oil until fragrant.
Add tripe, spices, and enough water to cover. Simmer 1.5 hours until tender.
Add tamarind juice, coconut milk, and salt. Simmer 30 minutes. Serve hot.
tips: Clean tripe thoroughly to remove odor.
Adjust tamarind for desired tanginess.
recipes.origin: A festive Malay soup, served at weddings and special occasions.

recipes.name: Epok-Epok (Malay Curry Puff)
recipes.description: Deep-fried pastry pockets filled with curried potatoes, sardines, or egg, a popular Malay snack.
steps: Rub butter into flour and salt, add water to form dough. Rest 30 minutes.
Fry onion, add potatoes, curry powder, and salt. Add sardines if using. Cook until potatoes are soft.
Roll dough thin, cut circles, fill with potato mixture and egg. Fold and seal edges.
Deep-fry until golden. Drain and serve.
tips: Seal edges well to prevent filling from leaking.
Serve with chilli sauce.
recipes.origin: A Malay snack, found at markets and food stalls in Singapore.

recipes.name: Kuih Lapis (Steamed Layer Cake)
recipes.description: Steamed, multi-layered cake of coconut milk and rice flour, a festive Peranakan and Malay treat.
steps: Mix batter ingredients, divide and color as desired.
Pour a thin layer into greased tray, steam 5 minutes. Repeat with alternating colors until all batter is used.
Cool, slice, and serve.
tips: Let each layer set before adding the next.
Use natural colors from pandan or beetroot.
recipes.origin: A festive kueh, popular at celebrations and markets.

recipes.name: Ang Ku Kueh
recipes.description: Steamed glutinous rice cakes with sweet mung bean or peanut filling, a festive Peranakan and Chinese treat.
steps: Mix dough ingredients to form a soft dough.
Blend steamed mung beans with sugar and oil to make filling.
Wrap filling in dough, press into ang ku kueh moulds.
Steam for 10 minutes. Cool before serving.
tips: Use sweet potato for softer skin.
Oil moulds to prevent sticking.
recipes.origin: A festive kueh, popular at full moon celebrations and markets.

recipes.name: Kueh Bongkong
recipes.description: Malay steamed glutinous rice cake with gula melaka filling, wrapped in banana leaves.
steps: Mix dough ingredients to form a soft dough.
Mix filling ingredients. Wrap filling in dough, shape into parcels, and wrap in banana leaves.
Steam for 1 hour. Cool before serving.
tips: Use fresh banana leaves for aroma.
Serve at room temperature.
recipes.origin: A Malay kueh, found at markets and festive occasions.

recipes.name: Kacang Pool
recipes.description: Malay-style fava bean stew with minced beef, spices, and fried egg, served with toasted bread.
steps: Fry onion, garlic, and ginger in oil until fragrant. Add minced beef, cook until browned.
Add spices and tomato, fry until oil separates.
Add fava beans, simmer 30 minutes. Season with salt.
Serve topped with fried egg, onion, green chilli, and toasted bread.
tips: Use canned fava beans for convenience.
Serve hot for best flavor.
recipes.origin: A Malay breakfast and snack, popular at hawker centres and markets.

recipes.name: Mee Rebus
recipes.description: A classic Malay noodle dish with yellow noodles in a thick, sweet-spicy gravy made from sweet potatoes, peanuts, fermented soybeans, and spices. Topped with egg, green chilies, fried shallots, and lime.
steps: Boil sweet potatoes until soft, then mash.
Blend shallots, garlic, ginger, dried shrimp, and taucheo into a paste.
Fry the paste in oil until fragrant. Add chili paste and curry powder, fry briefly.
Add mashed sweet potatoes, ground peanuts, water/stock, salt, and sugar. Simmer until thickened.
Blanch yellow noodles and bean sprouts. Place in bowls.
Ladle hot gravy over noodles. Top with egg, green chilies, fried shallots, bean sprouts, and a squeeze of lime.
tips: Use good quality sweet potatoes for a naturally sweet, thick gravy.
Adjust chili to taste for desired spiciness.
Add a spoonful of crispy fried tofu for extra texture.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Mee Rebus is a beloved Malay noodle dish found at hawker stalls across Singapore and Malaysia.

recipes.name: Mee Siam
recipes.description: A tangy, spicy Malay noodle dish of thin rice vermicelli in a tamarind-based gravy, topped with egg, tofu, chives, and lime.
steps: Blend shallots, garlic, dried shrimp, and taucheo into a paste.
Fry the paste in oil until fragrant. Add chili paste, fry briefly.
Add tamarind water, sugar, salt, and water/stock. Simmer to make a tangy gravy.
Blanch rice vermicelli and bean sprouts. Place in bowls.
Ladle hot gravy over noodles. Top with egg, tofu, chives, bean sprouts, and lime.
tips: Adjust tamarind and chili to taste for desired tanginess and heat.
Add prawns for extra flavor if desired.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Mee Siam is a popular Malay noodle dish found at hawker stalls and food courts across Singapore.

recipes.name: Dry Mee Siam
recipes.description: A stir-fried version of Mee Siam, with rice vermicelli tossed in a spicy, tangy sauce, served dry with egg, tofu, and lime.
steps: Blend shallots, garlic, dried shrimp, and taucheo into a paste.
Fry the paste in oil until fragrant. Add chili paste, fry briefly.
Add tamarind water, sugar, and salt. Simmer to make a thick sauce.
Add soaked rice vermicelli and bean sprouts. Stir-fry until well coated and dry.
Serve topped with egg, tofu, chives, and lime.
tips: Use less water for a drier version.
Add prawns or chicken for extra protein.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore hawker and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Dry Mee Siam is a favorite at Malay stalls, especially for breakfast or lunch.

recipes.name: Ramly Burger (Malaysian Street Burger)
recipes.description: A Malaysian street food icon: juicy beef or chicken patty, pan-fried and wrapped in an egg omelette, loaded with sauces, onions, and lettuce, all in a soft burger bun.
steps: Heat a little margarine or butter in a pan. Toast burger buns until golden, set aside.
Fry onion slices until soft and lightly browned, set aside.
Fry burger patties in oil until cooked through. Drizzle with Worcestershire and Maggi sauce while frying for extra flavor.
Push patty to one side of the pan. Crack an egg, spread it out into a thin omelette. Place patty in the center, fold egg around patty to wrap.
Assemble: Place lettuce and cheese (if using) on the bottom bun. Add the egg-wrapped patty, top with onions, and drizzle generously with chili sauce, mayonnaise, and black pepper sauce.
Cover with top bun and serve hot.
tips: For true Ramly style, use both chili and mayonnaise, and be generous with sauces!
You can add sliced cucumber or tomato for extra crunch.
Try with chicken, beef, or even double patties for a 'special' version.
recipes.source: Adapted from Malaysian street burger stalls and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: The Ramly Burger is a Malaysian invention, now a staple at night markets and street food stalls across Malaysia and Singapore.

recipes.name: Sambal Goreng (Fried Tempeh and Tofu)
recipes.description: A classic Malay/Indonesian side dish: fried tempeh and tofu tossed in a spicy, aromatic sambal with onions and sometimes long beans or potatoes.

seasoning.tamarind juice: 1 tbsp (from 1 tsp tamarind paste + 2 tbsp water)

steps: Deep-fry tempeh, tofu, and potatoes (if using) until golden. Drain and set aside.
Blend sambal paste ingredients until smooth.
Heat 2 tbsp oil in a wok. SautÃ© onion until soft, then add sambal paste. Fry until fragrant and oil separates.
Add tamarind juice, sugar, salt, and water. Simmer 2 minutes.
Add fried tempeh, tofu, potatoes, and long beans (if using). Toss to coat and cook until beans are just tender.
Adjust seasoning to taste. Serve hot or at room temperature.
tips: For a vegetarian version, omit belacan.
Add more chilies for extra heat, or more sugar for a sweeter style.
Sambal goreng keeps well and is great with rice or lontong.
recipes.source: Adapted from Singapore/Malaysia Malay home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Sambal Goreng is a staple at Malay stalls and festive tables, especially during Hari Raya.
